did.unittitle: Brooklyn Historical Society collection of fine art reproductions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dates reflect the dates of the original paintings not the date of reproduction.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn Historical Society collection of fine art reproductions, ARC.303, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The bulk of the collection remains protected under copyright. Please consult library staff for more information.

controlaccess.subject: Landscapes |z New York (State) |z Kings County

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of eight approximately 11" x 17" archival giclee prints on watercolor paper that are reproductions of watercolors by Oliver Smith printed by Broadway Art Enterprises, LLC in 2002. A few of these prints concern Brooklyn locations and two are derived from set designs for specific stage shows.

1. "Brooklyn Bridge #2" (from New York Cityscapes: Fine Art Watercolor) 2. "NY Harbor #1" (from New York Cityscapes: Fine Art Watercolor) 3. "NY Harbor #2" (from New York Cityscapes: Fine Art Watercolor) 4. "NY Harbor #3" (from New York Cityscapes: Fine Art Watercolor) 5. "Brooklyn Bridge #1" (from New York Cityscapes: Fine Art Watercolor) 6. "Brooklyn Heights" (from New York Cityscapes: Fine Art Watercolor) 7. "The Bowery #1 (Backdrop)" (from "Kelly (1965)") 8. "Coney Island (Backdrop)" (from On the Town (1944))

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

list.head: Sources
list.item: Anderson, Jack, "Oliver Smith, Set Designer, Dead at 75." New York Times, January 25, 1994.

bioghist.p: Oliver Smith was born in Waupun, Wisconsin, on February 13, 1918. He was a well-known set designer and served as a co-director of the American Ballet Theater.

He studied architecture at Pennsylvania State University, where he received a bachelor's degree in 1939. Shortly after his graduation from college, Mr. Smith moved to New York City. He shared a house in Brooklyn Heights with other talented young artists, including the composer Benjamin Britten and the writers W. H. Auden, Carson McCullers and Richard Wright.

He later bought and restored a four-story Federal-style house in Brooklyn Heights and used its attic as his studio. Over the years, several of its rooms served as the residence of illustrious house guests, including the theatrical director Sir Tyrone Guthrie and Truman Capote, who wrote the novel In Cold Blood there.

He designed such Broadway hits as "Brigadoon," "West Side Story," "My Fair Lady," "Camelot" and "Hello, Dolly!" and major ballets by such choreographers as Jerome Robbins, Agnes de Mille and Eliot Feld. By his own estimation in an interview, he had designed more than 250 productions by 1966. In addition to designing productions, Mr. Smith was occasionally a co-producer of plays and musicals. His first venture in this field was "On the Town," a successful musical.

Mr. Smith also taught scenic design at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University for 22 years. His paintings have been shown in exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum, the Chicago Art Institute and other institutions.
